original_title: Sri Lanka eyes “subsidiarisation of foreign banks” in changes to banking law
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Planned amendments to Sri Lanka’s Banking Act will include the subsidiarization of foreign banks, according to the text of a policy speech of Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe.
“The legal and regulatory framework of licensed banks is to be further strengthened through the proposed amendments to the Banking Act,” the policy speech said.

The changes involve minimum licensing requirements, corporate governance, shareholder suitability, acquisitions, mergers, disposal of non-financial subsidiaries, and “subsidiarisation of foreign banks, as deemed necessary.”
Sri Lanka’s foreign banks are now branches of an overseas headquartered entity.
There will be “consolidated supervision, accounts and audit, proportionality, large exposures, and related party transactions.”
The Banking (Amendment) Bill is expected to be passed in Parliament in early 2024. (Colombo/Jan10/2023)
